clinical_study.brief_title: Standard Precautions Versus Contact Additional Precautions Against Multi-drug Resistant Bacteria in Intensive Care Unit (PSBMR)
clinical_study.official_title: Are Standard Precautions as Efficient as Contact Additional Precautions Against the Transmission of Multi-drug Resistant Bacteria in Intensive Care Unit ?

brief_summary.textblock: The national recommendations promote the applying of the Contact Additional Precautions (CAP) with the Standard Precautions (SP) to limit the transmission of multi-drug resistant (MDR) bacteria. However, that could entail more costs and a reduction of quality of the patient care.

detailed_description.textblock:
The national recommendations promote the applying of the Contact Additional Precautions (CAP) with the Standard Precautions (SP) to limit the transmission of multi-drug resistant (MDR) bacteria. However, that could entail more costs and a reduction of quality of the patient care.
This study seeks showing it in way of a non-interventional research in a resuscitation unit. Two periods are compared for noticing the rates of MDR bacteria contaminations.

primary_outcome.measure: Rate of Meticillin Resistant Staphylococcus Aureus (MRSA) and Enterobacteriaceae producing Extended Spectrum Beta-Lactamase (EESBL) per 1000 hospitalization days

study_pop.textblock: All patients hospitalized in the resuscitation unit of the study

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- hospitalization in resuscitation unit
Exclusion Criteria:
- opposition for gathering data
